node.title: André Leon Talley in His Own Words
node.description: “We’re living in such a vulgar age!,” the unfiltered fashion editor once said.
node.content: ["Andr\u00e9 Leon Talley was the last of his kind: a fashion editor who operated without the filter of a corporate public relations apparatus.", "He made broad, extravagant declarations like, \u201cWe\u2019re living in such a vulgar age!\u201d He was the \u201cpharaoh of fabulosity\u201d who put himself on his own best-dressed lists and eviscerated celebrities whose red carpet ensembles weren\u2019t up to his standards. In short, Andr\u00e9 Leon Talley spoke his mind, seemingly without fear.", "\u201cWhen he likes it, he says it very loud, and when he doesn\u2019t like it, he says it very loud, too,\u201d his friend, the designer Carolina Herrera, told Vanity Fair in 2013. \u201cHe\u2019s either a volcano or an iceberg.\u201d", "Here, highlights from three decades of his life inside \u2014 and, later, far outside \u2014 the fashion system.", "\u201cWhen I was 14, my uncle asked what I wanted to be, and I said a fashion editor. He began screaming, \u2018Scandal! Scandal! Scandal!\u2019 My grandmother just looked at me.\u201d", "The New York Times, 1992", "\u201cEverything in life is about editing, whether it is editing your food, editing your clothes, editing the flowers, editing your room, editing your time.\u201d", "T: The New York Times Style Magazine, 2014", "\u201cYou can be aristocratic, without having been born into an aristocratic family.\u201d", "\u201cThe Gospel According to Andr\u00e9 Leon Talley,\u201d 2018", "\u201cIn the world of fashion, you have to be hidden to survive. Think of Halston, Tom Ford, Karl Lagerfeld. They were very much cryptotic. They saw themselves as playing a role to their public. Who in the world really knows who they are?\u201d", "The New York Times, 2003", "\u201cThere is a sophistication lacking in American clothes. Everyone thinks it\u2019s enough to put a pale blue cashmere sweater in six-ply with a terra-cotta skirt and call it fashion.\u201d", "The New York Times, 1999", "\u201cThe world has no choice. It must embrace and glorify the gay aesthetic.\u201d", "The Advocate, 1992", "\u201cI would never be so rude as to say, \u2018You look bad.\u2019\u201d \u201cI would say, \u2018Oh, who made that?\u2019 and my eyebrows would raise to the ceiling, and there would be a silence.\u201d", "Vanity Fair, 2013", "\u201cToo many career women look like a herd of fashion beasts, aping one another in impractical shoes.\u201d", "Vogue, 2009", "\u201cI have more than 10 and less than 50. Listen, I\u2019m not Marie Antoinette.\u201d", "The New York Times, 2016", "\u201cI\u2019ve shopped everywhere! I go to Kmart, I go to Wal-Mart, I go to Sam\u2019s Club, I go to Target. I love those stores. One of the most therapeutic things you can do is go to Target with a basket and a trolley.\u201d", "The Cut, 2008", "\u201cThere\u2019s nothing worse than a woman with a camel toe at a cocktail party because then your eyes look at that and you don\u2019t want to talk to her. You throw your hair back and you keep walking.\u201d", "The Wall Street Journal, 2010", "\u201cI personally go to the airport looking like a homeless person, because I think people will leave me alone. But I dress myself with my luggage \u2014 all my luggage matches. But it\u2019s so humiliating to be searched, and they take away your lotions \u2014 you just bought a $15 bottle of Kiehl\u2019s, and it\u2019s too big. You just never know what you\u2019re going to get. So it\u2019s better to just go as an anonymous person from Dallas.\u201d", "The Cut, 2010", "\u201cWhenever I see the red-carpet shows, I wonder what happened to these people. Who told them to get dressed that way?\u201d", "The Cut, 2010", "\u201cI may have had moments of hauteur. H-A-U-T-E-U-R. But I was never a snob. You can ask [Princess] Gloria von Thurn und Taxis, or [Lady] Amanda Harlech!\u201d", "The Guardian, 2020", "\u201cManolo will be in the kitchen cooking his wonderful cuisine, and I\u2019ll be in the larder, lacquering my Louis Vuitton cases with yacht varnish, bringing them to a high shine.\u201d", "The Guardian, 2020", "\u201cIt\u2019s not about going and buying the most extraordinary set of luggage or the most extraordinary ring or six-ply cashmere sweater \u00ad\u00ad\u00ad\u2014 that\u2019s luxury, too \u2014 but luxury can also be you having lunch with your best friend Karl Lagerfeld.\u201d", "Yale Daily News, 2010", "\u201cI reconcile the toxicity of the fashion world with the beauty of home.\u201d", "The New York Times, 2010", "\u201cI live alone. I\u2019ll die alone, I climbed up alone, and I\u2019ll go down alone.\u201d", "The New York Times, 2018"]
